title: How to adjust the pH of bleach safely - Quora

response.answer_text: You should be doing this under the supervision of someone who can answer the question for you! The fact that you apparently do NOT have any such supervision makes me think you’d be better leaving it alone. I have pH solution curves on chlorine in water . . . somewhere, but nowhere I can lay hands on them quickly. But without them, you will face an unpredicted point at which your solution will suddenly began releasing chlorine gas. Personally, I wouldn’t trust a fume hood in an environment where students are “adjusting the pH of bleach” without knowledgeable supervision. And yes, Virginia, there are cases of cheap-ass construction where fume hood vents are made of zinc plated carbon steel . . . or simply terminate in the attic. Neither of these cases would work out well for you, if you begin venting chlorine gas. And if the vent fan is ALSO carbon steel, and suddenly fails while you are accidentally venting chlorine gas . . . things may be even worse. Good luck; you need it! [PS. If you are a determined sort of dumb-ass . . . take your experiment OUTSIDE! At least that way, so long as you only use small quantities (100 ml of bleach or less), you probably won’t hurt anyone! ]
